anxiety_info.title: Why do we feel anxious?
anxiety_info.description: Anxiety is not an enemy trying to hurt us; it’s a signal from the heart to keep us safe.

step1.title: Anxiety is an alarm for survival
content: Since ancient times, anxiety has been a helpful alarm protecting us from danger.
It's an instinctive signal from the brain shouting, "Be careful!"
So, feeling anxious means your survival instinct is working perfectly and healthily.

step2.title: It rolls in and out like waves
content: Anxiety doesn't stay in our hearts forever.
Just like waves in the ocean, it slowly rises, reaches its peak, and then gently subsides.
This anxiety might feel like it will last forever, but remember, every wave is bound to pass.

step3.title: The more you block it, the bigger it gets
content: What happens if you try to block a rushing wave with your bare body?
You'll likely feel a greater impact or be swept away more easily.
Anxiety is the same. The more you resist it, the more fiercely it crashes over your surface.

step4.title: Soothe your sensitive alarm
content: In modern life, the alarm often rings even when there’s no real danger.
Instead of trying to break the alarm, it’s important to acknowledge its state first.
Gently say to yourself, "The alarm is ringing right now. I'm feeling tense."

step5.title: Moving forward with anxiety
content: You don't have to get rid of anxiety entirely to be happy.
Just as the deep current doesn't lose its way even when surface waves are high,
we can move toward the life we want while holding our anxiety within.

act_guide.title: Moving Forward with Anxiety
act_guide.description: Instead of fighting anxiety, let's learn about ACT—a way to move toward the life you want, even when you feel anxious.

step1.title: What is ACT?
content: ACT (Acceptance and Commitment Therapy) is a psychology that helps you accept anxiety as it is,
and commit to taking action toward the values you hold dear.
Our app breaks this process down into 5 easy steps for you to follow.

step2.title: Rising to the surface of the present
content: When you're caught in a whirlpool of thoughts, try Step 1 (Grounding) and Step 2 (Emotion Diary).
By focusing on your senses and recording the weather of your heart,
you'll find your deep, calm sea that stays steady amidst the rough waves.

step3.title: Separating thoughts from facts
content: Step 3 (Separating Wind and Waves) helps you view thoughts like "I will fail" objectively.
It's a practice of separating the "thought" part from the rest of the sentence.
Remember, thoughts are just wind brushing across the surface, not absolute facts.

step4.title: Flowing with the rhythm of waves
content: In Step 4 (Deepening the Sea), try breathing along with the rising and falling wave animations.
Instead of pushing anxiety away, create a space within your deep sea for it to simply stay.
As you breathe in and out, let the wave of anxiety just flow through you.

step5.title: Moving toward my own values
content: In the final step, discover the values you truly cherish and take action.
Even if you feel anxious, you can still take small steps toward your values.
Start with a small action today, while holding your anxiety within.
